Award.AwardTitle: Nuclear Reaction and Structure Studies with Radioactive and Stable beams
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project involves the study of nuclear reactions utilizing beams of short-lived radioactive nuclei, together with the development of instrumentation and techniques to facilitate these investigations. Specific experiments will emphasize the study of neutron- and proton-rich nuclei near the limits of nuclear stability. Several of these weakly bound systems have been shown to develop an exotic "nuclear halo" structure, leading to an effective nuclear size that is much larger than expected based on the properties of more normal systems. Our interest is in the effect that this structure has on nuclear reactions induced by "halo" nuclei." The development of deuterated-scintillator neutron detectors for this project may have applications to national-security programs. In addition, we plan to use specific nuclear reactions to probe the structure of nuclei that are important for the understanding of neutrinoless double beta decay. Several massive and expensive experiments are underway to search for this exotic decay mode, which would represent physics beyond the so-called standard model of particle interactions. If observed, this decay mode would also present a means to directly measure the mass of the neutrino, which is important for subjects such as high-energy physics, astronomy, and cosmology. However, this application requires much-improved knowledge of the structure of the nuclei involved in the beta-decay process. The experiments we are planning to carry out will contribute to the development of this understanding.

In addition to the already-mentioned contributions of instrumentation development to national-security issues, the broader impact of this project extends to the development of a scientifically-literate workforce via the involvement of students at the graduate, undergraduate, and high-school levels in world-class scientific research. These groups are afforded opportunities for hands-on training in nuclear accelerators, superconducting ion-optical systems, radiation detection, and other technologies. The undergraduate students come from Notre Dame and the University of Michigan, and also from several primarily-undergraduate universities and colleges in the Midwest. The high-school program includes public lectures and other outreach activities designed to highlight nuclear science and its applications to other fields such as archaeology and medicine. Finally, the program has an international component involving close collaborations with physicists in Mexico and Brazil, and new collaborations including the UK, France, and Italy are proposed.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project involves the study of nuclear reactions utilizing short-lived radioactive nuclear beams (RNBs) together with the development of instrumentation, techniques, and apparatus to facilitate these studies.  Specific early experiments emphasized the investigation of the structure and reaction mechanisms of very neutron- and proton-rich nuclei near the very limits of nuclear stability, i.e., the boundary between normal, stable nuclei and those that decay and are unstable. In the last three years of the project, much of the research and development work has been in support of the forthcoming Facility for Rare Isotope Beams (FRIB), a new national user facility funded by the US Department of Energy currently under construction nearby at Michigan State University (MSU).  For example, several experiments have recently been carried out using the prototype active-target time projection chamber (pAT-TPC) nuclear-particle tracking detector developed at MSU and subsequently connected to the beam line of the Notre Dame (ND) RNB facility TwinSol.  One goal of this particular research work was to develop and test critical components of the device, providing essential feedback and operational experience for the development of a full-scale AT-TPC, twice the size, which has now been installed at the MSU research facility.  Another goal was to carry out important experiments using the device itself at ND.  As just one example, we have recently carried out an experiment to investigate the structure of the so-called "Hoyle state" in Carbon-12, which accounts for the production of carbon in stars and is the ultimate source of almost all of the carbon on Earth and in the Universe, essential for life.  The structure of this nuclear  state is therefore relevant for the understanding of carbon-based life on this Earth and, possibly, elsewhere in the Universe.   Another important project was the development of a new generation of "deuterated-scintillator" neutron detectors for use in neutron spectroscopy.  These devices have important applications to national security programs as they can detect neutrons emitted by nuclear materials used in weapons and identify those materials. They are also proving  useful in experiments to study neutron-producing reactions that are relevant for nuclear astrophysics and the creation of the elements.  As an example, we have recently used these detectors at the TwinSol facility to study nuclear reactions with short-lived radioactive nuclei that are involved in the production of certain important chemical elements in supernova explosions of stars.  Our work has increasingly turned towards these astrophysics-related projects.  Finally, we have begun a study aimed at determining very precise lifetimes of certain radioactive isotopes that are important for the study of the fundamental interactions that determine the state of the early Universe and its ultimate fate.
